Every NFL team plays exactly four pre-season exhibition games a year, two of which are "home" games (in other words, played in their home stadium) and two which are "away" games. The team in each of the four home "away" games plays the other team the next week and the teams play their "home" and "away" opponents the following week. Each team only plays four pre-season games, but there is a long-term schedule for each team in the preseason and postseason. Each team starts the preseason in the same week it goes onto the field for the regular season. For instance, the Philadelphia Eagles begin the first preseason game on Thursday, April 13, and finish the fourth preseason game on Sunday, April 20.

original: Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. Light-dark color variation is common in the mammalian taxa. Sometimes, this color variation is determined by age variation, however, in other cases, it is determined by other factors. Selective pressures, such as ecological interactions with other populations or environmental conditions, often lead to the variation in mammalian coloration. These selective pressures favor certain colors in order to increase survival. Camouflage is thought to be a major selection pressure shaping coloration in mammals, although there is also evidence that sexual selection, communication, and physiological processes may influence the evolution of coloration as well. Camouflage is the most predominant mechanism for color variation, as it aids in the concealment of the organisms from predators or from their prey. Coat color can also be for intraspecies communication such as warning members of their species about predators, indicating health for reproductive purposes, communicating between mother and young, and intimidating predators. Mammalian hair, also known as pelage, can vary in color between populations, organisms within a population, and even on the individual organism. This variation between populations and species is one of the primary means of differentiation among mammals.

Some mammals have a large number of hairs on one side of the face, such as the mouse. Such a hair appears on the face of one or both sides of the upper lip, under the chin, and is arranged in a ring around the eyes. The hairs are dark in color and are usually small. A few mammals such as the rhesus macaque, an important research model, have very few hair follicles on one side of the face, the eyebrows.

Some individuals will be unable to breed as a result of adverse selection, so their FST falls above the fixed population size threshold. If an individual is not able to breed with any individual, it would be expected the FST would fall below the fixed population size threshold.

In southeast Europe agrarian societies first appeared in the 7th millennium BC, attested by one of the earliest farming sites of Europe, discovered in the Neolithic village of Yohņa, Croatia. However, for most of recorded history, agriculture and foraging were inter-twined, in a way that still applies today, which is one of the main reasons why there have been significant and mutually beneficial relationships between modern humans and traditional (and sometimes even semi-modern) societies in general. A simple example of this is that of the domestication of plants, the introduction of cattle, and later the establishment of grain-based economies. original: Identity development is a stage in the adolescent life cycle. For most, the search for identity begins in the adolescent years. During these years, adolescents are more open to 'trying on' different behaviours and appearances to discover who they are. In other words, in an attempt to find their identity and discover who they are adolescents are liking to cycle through a number of identities to find one that suits them best. But, developing and maintaining identity (in adolescent years) is a difficult task due to multiple factors such as family life, environment, and social status. Empirical studies suggest that this process might be more accurately described as identity development, rather than formation, but confirms a normative process of change in both content and structure of one's thoughts about the self. The two main aspects of identity development are self-clarity and self-esteem. During these years, adolescents begin to ask probing questions and attempt to find an answer. As adolescents grow to develop into adults, the desire to have an identity becomes increasingly important.

In most Jewish populations, these founder events probably represent, at best, a very small subset of all the Jews. original: Like the reptiles, birds are primarily uricotelic, that is, their kidneys extract nitrogenous waste from their bloodstream and excrete it as uric acid instead of urea or ammonia through the ureters into the intestine. Birds do not have a urinary bladder or external urethral opening and (with exception of the ostrich) uric acid is excreted along with feces as a semisolid waste. However, birds such as hummingbirds can be facultatively ammonotelic, excreting most of the nitrogenous wastes as ammonia. They also excrete creatine, rather than creatinine like mammals. This material, as well as the output of the intestines, emerges from the bird's cloaca. The cloaca is a multi-purpose opening: waste is expelled through it, most birds mate by joining cloaca, and females lay eggs from it. In addition, many species of birds regurgitate pellets. Instead their high uric acid content is taken up in a form similar to urea, used to produce urea which then converts to urochromes and urea-glucuronide. In Homer's Iliad, the names Danaans (or Danaoi: Δαναοί) and Argives (Argives in Greek) are both generic terms for the Indo-European people of what will become the Balkans. In contrast to their western brethren, the Iranian peoples to whom the Greeks later attributed names such as Danaos and Homeros, the Danaan and the Argive peoples were Indo-Europeans who first appeared in the Aegean and Greek world ca. 2500 bc – ca. 2350 bc with settlements of this type spread from Athens to Sicily.

During the first great wave of the Indo-European expansion from ca. 1600 bc to 300 bc, the Danaans were part of this demographic wave. The Homeric epics (and their successors) in fact mention both the Danaans and the Argives. The treaty effectively ended the Mexican war , establishing the territorial boundaries of the United States , Mexico , and California . In exchange for the acquisition of the ceded territory , the United States paid Mexico $ 15 million , agreed to assume Mexican debts to US citizens , and settled the claims of Mexican citizens against Americans . The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo was signed by Mexican representative Umar an and American diplomat Trist , but it needed the appro val of the Mexican cabinet and the US Senate . Sound could be stored in either analog or digital format and in a variety of surround sound formats; NTSC discs could carry two analog audio tracks, plus or minus one, while PAL-specification discs could carry three analog audio tracks, plus or minus two.

Sound was stored in the sound device. Audio signals were transmitted directly to the sound device and then encoded into a standard bit stream, which could then be decoded at the sound device. The signal could be stored on a magnetic disk or recorded on to a phonograph disc.

Because of the way these machines stored sound, some sources such as a tape may be better than others. For example, a phonograph may sound better than vinyl on some types of recordings. Also, a tape will retain more information than any other medium. For example, the sounds from many recordings might require many times more information than music available in a compact disc.

Jean Macfarlane founded the University of California, Berkeley's Institute of Human Development, formerly called the Institute of Child Welfare, in 1927. The Institute was designed to provide research, education and supervision to improve educational and child-rearing practices. Macfarlane was a pioneer of gender studies and a leading proponent of the feminist movement.

Over the decades, the Institute continued to evolve with Macfarlane's passing in 1976, and the Institute's faculty and affiliates became stronger. The Institute's most recent director, the feminist scholar Donna Haraway, received the 1993 American Psychological Association Award for distinguished service to psychology, as well as the 1993 American Psychological Association Women's Leadership Award.

Through its programs and fellowships, the Institute supports graduate students and undergraduate scholars in human development with opportunities for research, teaching and research training. The Institute also supports the graduate and professional schools, libraries and archives of the University of California, Berkeley.

A board-only organization is a special type of nonprofit organization the bylaws are made by the board rather than elected and is controlled by officers, often the organization's president. The board of directors can adopt bylaws that override and supersede the bylaws of the membership organization.

Many cultures define the transition into adultlike sexuality by specific biological or social milestones in an adolescent's life. For example, menarche (the first physical manifestation of puberty) is considered one such milestone. But as a society, we haven't always agreed on what this milestone is and how age should be measured. We continue to debate whether a teenager who is able to pull off a tuxedo or take a sip of beer is really 16 years old and, if so, whether their body is ready for those things.

original: Microbiological culture is a principal tool used to diagnose infectious disease. In a microbial culture, a growth medium is provided for a specific agent. Young children tend to assert themselves forcefully, but are unable to demonstrate much influence over family decisions until early adolescence, when they are increasingly viewed by parents as equals. original: Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people. An exclusive boundary arises, for example, when a person adopts a marker that imposes restrictions on the behaviour of others. An inclusive boundary is created, by contrast, by the use of a marker with which other people are ready and able to associate. At the same time, however, an inclusive boundary will also impose restrictions on the people it has included by limiting their inclusion within other boundaries. completed: Boundaries can be inclusive or exclusive depending on how they are perceived by other people . An exclusive boundary arises , for example , when a person adopts a marker that is associated with a group that the other person does not share . This exclusion occurs because the marker is defined in terms of a group with boundaries that do not permit outsiders . Inclusion , in contrast , comes from the recognition of the other person as a member of one 's own group . For example , children can be asked whether the children from a neighboring school are their classmates . original: To maintain a high constant body temperature is energy expensive – mammals therefore need a nutritious and plentiful diet. While the earliest mammals were probably predators, different species have since adapted to meet their dietary requirements in a variety of ways. Some eat other animals – this is a carnivorous diet (and includes insectivorous diets). Other mammals, called herbivores, eat plants. A herbivorous diet includes subtypes such as fruit-eating and grass-eating. An omnivore eats both prey and plants. Carnivorous mammals have a simple digestive tract, because the proteins, lipids, and minerals found in meat require little in the way of specialized digestion. Plants, on the other hand, contain complex carbohydrates, such as cellulose. The digestive tract of an herbivore is therefore host to bacteria that ferment these substances, and make them available for digestion. The bacteria are either housed in the multichambered stomach or in a large cecum. The size of an animal is also a factor in determining diet

original: To prevent the risk of out-of-phase supplies mixing, sections of line fed from different feeder stations must be kept strictly isolated. This is achieved by Neutral Sections (also known as Phase Breaks), usually provided at feeder stations and midway between them although, typically, only half are in use at any time, the others being provided to allow a feeder station to be shut down and power provided from adjacent feeder stations. Neutral Sections usually consist of an earthed section of wire which is separated from the live wires on either side by insulating material, typically ceramic beads, designed so that the pantograph will smoothly run from one section to the other. The earthed section prevents an arc being drawn from one live section to the other, as the voltage difference may be higher than the normal system voltage if the live sections are on different phases and the protective circuit breakers may not be able to safely interrupt the considerable current that would flow. Over 20 percent identified as "multiculturized," in contrast to the general U.S. median of 19 percent. And more than 16 percent of those over 16 years old were born overseas, compared with 21 percent of the population as a whole and 10 percent among the foreign-born in the United States overall. Nearly two-thirds (65 percent) of the Chinese held master's or higher degrees, compared with 43 percent of the U.S. population. In 1681, in partial repayment of a debt, Charles II of England granted William Penn a charter for what would become the Pennsylvania colony. Despite the loss of the Great Charter following a series of rebellions, Penn continued to seek new tracts of land. With the help of Pennsylvania legislators, like the Honorable Nathaniel Bradford, he acquired two tracts near Plymouth and another near Philadelphia.

The Treaty of London on April 29, 1691 placed responsibility for paying the debts of the Dutch colony with the French colony. The payment was intended to satisfy the colonists who had protested against payment. After a series of violent raids, in 1692 Penn agreed to cede to the settlers in his lands four of the eight parcels that had been ceded by his predecessor.

In 1693 Penn signed the Treaty of Paris. The next year, Penn's father, Sir John Penn, was born in Holland. The Penns came to North America later that year, sailing from England with the first colonists.

original: Plumage is regularly moulted; the standard plumage of a bird that has moulted after breeding is known as the "non-breeding" plumage, or—in the Humphrey-Parkes terminology—"basic" plumage; breeding plumages or variations of the basic plumage are known under the Humphrey-Parkes system as "alternate" plumages. Moulting is annual in most species, although some may have two moults a year, and large birds of prey may moult only once every few years. Moulting patterns vary across species. In passerines, flight feathers are replaced one at a time with the innermost primary being the first. When the fifth of sixth primary is replaced, the outermost tertiaries begin to drop. After the innermost tertiaries are moulted, the secondaries starting from the innermost begin to drop and this proceeds to the outer feathers (centrifugal moult). The greater primary coverts are moulted in synchrony with the primary that they overlap.

The phenomenalist phase of post-Humean empiricism ended by the 1940s, for by that time it had become obvious that statements about physical reality had very different implications from statements about mental objects. Physical states are no longer simply mental objects on which to pin our attention, but are rather something much deeper to be looked at in terms of what it means for a set of statements to be true or false. For instance, statements about the motion of a ship cannot be regarded as true or false because motion does not occur at all in the mind and no laws or relationships exist to connect a thought about motion with the actual motion of the ship itself.

Despite the growing appreciation of the fundamental difference between physical and mental states of affairs, the phenomenalist, despite being generally a naturalist, felt a sort of hesitance to drop his metaphysics in response to physicalism. Copper occurs naturally as native copper and was known to some of the oldest civilizations on record. It has a history of use that is at least 10,000 years old, and its use in jewellery has been documented from 5000 BC. Its use in jewelry has continued into the present-day.

The most interesting thing about copper is the amount of copper it contains, and the fact that it is a metal with a fairly high melting point. Copper is a metal with an extremely large amount of energy stored in it, and the heat produced during the melting process can be used to create electricity. One of the reasons why the Romans used copper rather than iron for their weapons was the fact that copper held a higher thermal conductivity compared to iron. A high heat transfer coefficient allowed more heat to be carried away in one direction, making the metal the ideal choice for weapons.

They may not always do well in new habitats, and they can also encounter human health hazards, such as antibiotic-resistant diseases. In biology, energy is an attribute of all biological systems from the biosphere to the smallest living organism. Within an organism it is responsible for growth and reproduction; it is involved in the regulation and elimination of toxins; it is responsible for the production and destruction of cell structures, including the cell nucleus [9]. Energy is a major determinant (pigment and enzyme, especially) of physical, chemical and biological processes. It represents the sum of all work done within the cell. completed: The works of Virgil almost from the moment of their publication revolutionized Latin poetry . The Eclogues , Georgics , and above all the Aeneid became standard texts in school curricula throughout Western Europe until the modern period . As Virgil himself claimed in the Prose Editions , the Aeneid was a literary monument and the best poem in Latin , and this opinion was taken as self-evident over many centuries . The Aeneid did not , however , receive the same universal acceptance and admiration as the works of the Greek po ets , most notably Homer , whom Virgil himself cited in the preface ― and Virgil was aware of his debt and indebtedness toward Homer ― even as he himself made no effort to imitate Homer . original: Throughout the history of the South Slavs, the vernacular, literary, and written languages (e.g. Chakavian, Kajkavian, Shtokavian) of the various regions and ethnicities developed and diverged independently. Prior to the 19th century, they were collectively called "Illyric", "Slavic", "Slavonian", "Bosnian", "Dalmatian", "Serbian" or "Croatian". As such, the term Serbo-Croatian was first used by Jacob Grimm in 1824, popularized by the Vienna philologist Jernej Kopitar in the following decades, and accepted by Croatian Zagreb grammarians in 1854 and 1859.
